virtual const Elem* libMesh::MeshBase::query_elem ( const dof_id_type  i) const
inlinevirtualinherited

Return a pointer to the element, or NULL if no such element exists in this processor's mesh data structure.

This method is deprecated; use the less confusingly-named query_elem_ptr() instead.

libMesh::libmesh_assert

libMesh::DistributedMesh::_nodes

Definition: distributed_mesh.h:467
void libMesh::UnstructuredMesh::read ( const std::string &  name,
MeshData *  mesh_data = libmesh_nullptr,
bool  skip_renumber_nodes_and_elements = false,
bool  skip_find_neighbors = false 
)
virtualinherited

Reads the file specified by name. Attempts to figure out the proper method by the file extension. This is now the only way to read a mesh. The UnstructuredMesh then initializes its data structures and is ready for use.

In order to read the UNV and TetGen file types, you must also pass a separate pointer to the MeshData object you will use with this mesh, since these read methods expect it.

The skip_renumber_nodes_and_elements argument is now deprecated - to disallow renumbering, set MeshBase::allow_renumbering(false).

Set skip_find_neighbors=true to skip the find-neighbors operation during prepare_for_use. This operation isn't always necessary and it can be time-consuming, which is why we provide an option to skip it.

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

Definition at line 577 of file unstructured_mesh.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::allow_renumbering(), libMesh::MeshBase::prepare_for_use(), libMesh::NameBasedIO::read(), libMesh::TetGenIO::read(), and libMesh::UNVIO::read().

581 {
582  // Set the skip_renumber_nodes_and_elements flag on all processors
583  // if necessary.
584  // This ensures that renumber_nodes_and_elements is *not* called
585  // during prepare_for_use() for certain types of mesh files.
586  // This is required in cases where there is an associated solution
587  // file which expects a certain ordering of the nodes.
588  if (name.rfind(".gmv") + 4 == name.size())
589  this->allow_renumbering(false);
590 
591  if (mesh_data)
592  {
593  libmesh_deprecated();
594  if (name.rfind(".unv") < name.size())
595  UNVIO(*this, mesh_data).read (name);
596  else if ((name.rfind(".node") < name.size()) ||
597  (name.rfind(".ele") < name.size()))
598  TetGenIO(*this,mesh_data).read (name);
599  }
600  else
601  NameBasedIO(*this).read(name);
602 
603  if (skip_renumber_nodes_and_elements)
604  {
605  // Use MeshBase::allow_renumbering() yourself instead.
606  libmesh_deprecated();
607  this->allow_renumbering(false);
608  }
609 
610  // Done reading the mesh. Now prepare it for use.
611  this->prepare_for_use(/*skip_renumber (deprecated)*/ false,
612  skip_find_neighbors);
613 }

libMesh::MeshBase::allow_renumbering
bool allow_renumbering() const
Definition: mesh_base.h:686
unsigned int libMesh::MeshBase::recalculate_n_partitions ( )
inherited

In a few (very rare) cases, the user may have manually tagged the elements with specific processor IDs by hand, without using a partitioner. In this case, the Mesh will not know that the total number of partitions, _n_parts, has changed, unless you call this function. This is an O(N active elements) calculation. The return value is the number of partitions, and _n_parts is also set by this function.

Definition at line 489 of file mesh_base.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::_n_parts, libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_begin(), libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_end(), libMesh::ParallelObject::comm(), end, std::max(), and libMesh::Parallel::Communicator::max().

495  const_element_iterator end = this->active_local_elements_end();
496 
497  unsigned int max_proc_id=0;
498 
499  for (; el!=end; ++el)
500  max_proc_id = std::max(max_proc_id, static_cast<unsigned int>((*el)->processor_id()));
501 
502  // The number of partitions is one more than the max processor ID.
503  _n_parts = max_proc_id+1;
504

506 
507  return _n_parts;

void libMesh::DistributedMesh::redistribute ( )

Redistribute elements between processors. This gets called automatically by the Partitioner, and is a no-op in the case of a serialized mesh.

template<typename T >
dof_id_type libMesh::DistributedMesh::renumber_dof_objects ( mapvector< T *, dof_id_type > &  objects)

Renumber a parallel objects container Returns the smallest globally unused id for that container.

Definition at line 977 of file distributed_mesh.C.

References libMesh::Parallel::Communicator::allgather(), libMesh::mapvector< Val, index_t >::begin(), libMesh::ParallelObject::comm(), libMesh::mapvector< Val, index_t >::end(), end, libMesh::mapvector< Val, index_t >::erase(), libMesh::DofObject::invalid_processor_id, libMesh::DofObject::invalid_unique_id, libMesh::libmesh_assert(), libmesh_nullptr, libMesh::ParallelObject::n_processors(), libMesh::MeshTools::Subdivision::next, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), libMesh::Parallel::Communicator::send_receive(), and libMesh::Parallel::verify().

Referenced by renumber_nodes_and_elements().

978 {
979  // This function must be run on all processors at once
980  parallel_object_only();
981 
982  typedef typename mapvector<T *,dof_id_type>::veclike_iterator object_iterator;
983 
984  // In parallel we may not know what objects other processors have.
985  // Start by figuring out how many
986  dof_id_type unpartitioned_objects = 0;
987 
988  std::vector<dof_id_type>
989  ghost_objects_from_proc(this->n_processors(), 0);
990 
991  object_iterator it = objects.begin();
992  object_iterator end = objects.end();
993 
994  for (; it != end;)
995  {
996  T * obj = *it;
997 
998  // Remove any NULL container entries while we're here,
999  // being careful not to invalidate our iterator
1000  if (!*it)
1001  objects.erase(it++);
1002  else
1003  {
1004  processor_id_type obj_procid = obj->processor_id();
1005  if (obj_procid == DofObject::invalid_processor_id)
1006  unpartitioned_objects++;
1007  else
1008  ghost_objects_from_proc[obj_procid]++;
1009  ++it;
1010  }
1011  }
1012 
1013  std::vector<dof_id_type> objects_on_proc(this->n_processors(), 0);
1014  this->comm().allgather(ghost_objects_from_proc[this->processor_id()],
1015  objects_on_proc);
1016 
1017 #ifndef NDEBUG
1018  libmesh_assert(this->comm().verify(unpartitioned_objects));
1019  for (processor_id_type p=0; p != this->n_processors(); ++p)
1020  libmesh_assert_less_equal (ghost_objects_from_proc[p], objects_on_proc[p]);
1021 #endif
1022 
1023  // We'll renumber objects in blocks by processor id
1024  std::vector<dof_id_type> first_object_on_proc(this->n_processors());
1025  for (processor_id_type i=1; i != this->n_processors(); ++i)
1026  first_object_on_proc[i] = first_object_on_proc[i-1] +
1027  objects_on_proc[i-1];
1028  dof_id_type next_id = first_object_on_proc[this->processor_id()];
1029  dof_id_type first_free_id =
1030  first_object_on_proc[this->n_processors()-1] +
1031  objects_on_proc[this->n_processors()-1] +
1032  unpartitioned_objects;
1033 
1034  // First set new local object ids and build request sets
1035  // for non-local object ids
1036 
1037  // Request sets to send to each processor
1038  std::vector<std::vector<dof_id_type> >
1039  requested_ids(this->n_processors());
1040 
1041 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1042  std::vector<std::vector<unique_id_type> >
1043  requested_unique_ids(this->n_processors());
1044 #endif
1045 
1046  // We know how many objects live on each processor, so reseve() space for
1047  // each.
1048  for (processor_id_type p=0; p != this->n_processors(); ++p)
1049  if (p != this->processor_id())
1050  {
1051  requested_ids[p].reserve(ghost_objects_from_proc[p]);
1052 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1053  requested_unique_ids[p].reserve(ghost_objects_from_proc[p]);
1054 #endif
1055  }
1056 
1057  end = objects.end();
1058  for (it = objects.begin(); it != end; ++it)
1059  {
1060  T * obj = *it;
1061  if (obj->processor_id() == this->processor_id())
1062  obj->set_id(next_id++);
1063  else if (obj->processor_id() != DofObject::invalid_processor_id)
1064  {
1065  requested_ids[obj->processor_id()].push_back(obj->id());
1066 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1067  // It's possible to have an invalid id for dofs not owned by this process.
1068  // We'll assert that they match on the receiving end.
1069  requested_unique_ids[obj->processor_id()].push_back(obj->valid_unique_id() ? obj-> unique_id() : DofObject::invalid_unique_id);
1070 #endif
1071  }
1072  }
1073 
1074  // Next set ghost object ids from other processors
1075  if (this->n_processors() > 1)
1076  {
1077  for (processor_id_type p=1; p != this->n_processors(); ++p)
1078  {
1079  // Trade my requests with processor procup and procdown
1080  processor_id_type procup = cast_int<processor_id_type>
1081  ((this->processor_id() + p) % this->n_processors());
1082  processor_id_type procdown = cast_int<processor_id_type>
1083  ((this->n_processors() + this->processor_id() - p) %
1084  this->n_processors());
1085  std::vector<dof_id_type> request_to_fill;
1086  this->comm().send_receive(procup, requested_ids[procup],
1087  procdown, request_to_fill);
1088 
1089 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1090  std::vector<unique_id_type> unique_request_to_fill;
1091  this->comm().send_receive(procup, requested_unique_ids[procup],
1092  procdown, unique_request_to_fill);
1093  std::vector<unique_id_type> new_unique_ids(unique_request_to_fill.size());
1094 #endif
1095 
1096  // Fill those requests
1097  std::vector<dof_id_type> new_ids(request_to_fill.size());
1098  for (std::size_t i=0; i != request_to_fill.size(); ++i)
1099  {
1100  T * obj = objects[request_to_fill[i]];
1101  libmesh_assert(obj);
1102  libmesh_assert_equal_to (obj->processor_id(), this->processor_id());
1103  new_ids[i] = obj->id();
1104 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1105  new_unique_ids[i] = obj->valid_unique_id() ? obj->unique_id() : DofObject::invalid_unique_id;
1106 #endif
1107 
1108  libmesh_assert_greater_equal (new_ids[i],
1109  first_object_on_proc[this->processor_id()]);
1110  libmesh_assert_less (new_ids[i],
1111  first_object_on_proc[this->processor_id()] +
1112  objects_on_proc[this->processor_id()]);
1113  }
1114 
1115  // Trade back the results
1116  std::vector<dof_id_type> filled_request;
1117  this->comm().send_receive(procdown, new_ids,
1118  procup, filled_request);
1119 
1120 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1121  std::vector<unique_id_type> unique_filled_request;
1122  this->comm().send_receive(procdown, new_unique_ids,
1123  procup, unique_filled_request);
1124 #endif
1125 
1126  // And copy the id changes we've now been informed of
1127  for (std::size_t i=0; i != filled_request.size(); ++i)
1128  {
1129  T * obj = objects[requested_ids[procup][i]];
1130  libmesh_assert (obj);
1131  libmesh_assert_equal_to (obj->processor_id(), procup);
1132  libmesh_assert_greater_equal (filled_request[i],
1133  first_object_on_proc[procup]);
1134  libmesh_assert_less (filled_request[i],
1135  first_object_on_proc[procup] +
1136  objects_on_proc[procup]);
1137  obj->set_id(filled_request[i]);
1138 
1139 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
1140  if (!obj->valid_unique_id() && unique_filled_request[i] != DofObject::invalid_unique_id)
1141  obj->set_unique_id() = unique_filled_request[i];
1142 #endif
1143  }
1144  }
1145  }
1146 
1147  // Next set unpartitioned object ids
1148  next_id = 0;
1149  for (processor_id_type i=0; i != this->n_processors(); ++i)
1150  next_id += objects_on_proc[i];
1151  for (it = objects.begin(); it != end; ++it)
1152  {
1153  T * obj = *it;
1154  if (obj->processor_id() == DofObject::invalid_processor_id)
1155  obj->set_id(next_id++);
1156  }
1157 
1158  // Finally shuffle around objects so that container indices
1159  // match ids
1160  end = objects.end();
1161  for (it = objects.begin(); it != end;)
1162  {
1163  T * obj = *it;
1164  if (obj) // don't try shuffling already-NULL entries
1165  {
1166  T * next = objects[obj->id()];
1167  // If we have to move this object
1168  if (next != obj)
1169  {
1170  // NULL out its original position for now
1171  // (our shuffling may put another object there shortly)
1172  *it = libmesh_nullptr;
1173 
1174  // There may already be another object with this id that
1175  // needs to be moved itself
1176  while (next)
1177  {
1178  // We shouldn't be trying to give two objects the
1179  // same id
1180  libmesh_assert_not_equal_to (next->id(), obj->id());
1181  objects[obj->id()] = obj;
1182  obj = next;
1183  next = objects[obj->id()];
1184  }
1185  objects[obj->id()] = obj;
1186  }
1187  }
1188  // Remove any container entries that were left as NULL,
1189  // being careful not to invalidate our iterator
1190  if (!*it)
1191  objects.erase(it++);
1192  else
1193  ++it;
1194  }
1195 
1196  return first_free_id;
1197 }

void libMesh::DistributedMesh::renumber_elem ( dof_id_type  old_id,
dof_id_type  new_id 
)
virtual

Changes the id of element old_id, both by changing elem(old_id)->id() and by moving elem(old_id) in the mesh's internal container. No element with the id new_id should already exist.

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

Definition at line 565 of file distributed_mesh.C.

References _elements, libMesh::DofObject::id(), libMesh::libmesh_assert(), and libMesh::DofObject::set_id().

567 {
568  Elem * el = _elements[old_id];
569  libmesh_assert (el);
570  libmesh_assert_equal_to (el->id(), old_id);
571 
572  el->set_id(new_id);
573  libmesh_assert (!_elements[new_id]);
574  _elements[new_id] = el;
575  _elements.erase(old_id);
576 }
libMesh::DistributedMesh::_elements

Definition: distributed_mesh.h:472
libMesh::libmesh_assert
libmesh_assert(remote_elem)
void libMesh::DistributedMesh::renumber_node ( dof_id_type  old_id,
dof_id_type  new_id 
)
virtual

Changes the id of node old_id, both by changing node(old_id)->id() and by moving node(old_id) in the mesh's internal container. No element with the id new_id should already exist.

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

Definition at line 738 of file distributed_mesh.C.

References _nodes, libMesh::DofObject::id(), libMesh::libmesh_assert(), and libMesh::DofObject::set_id().

740 {
741  Node * nd = _nodes[old_id];
742  libmesh_assert (nd);
743  libmesh_assert_equal_to (nd->id(), old_id);
744 
745  nd->set_id(new_id);
746 
747  // If we have nodes shipped to this processor for NodeConstraints
748  // use, then those nodes will exist in _nodes, but may not be
749  // locatable via a TopologyMap due to the insufficiency of elements
750  // connecting to them. If local refinement then wants to create a
751  // *new* node in the same location, it will initally get a temporary
752  // id, and then make_node_ids_parallel_consistent() will try to move
753  // it to the canonical id. We need to account for this case to
754  // avoid false positives and memory leaks.
755 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_NODE_CONSTRAINTS
756  if (_nodes[new_id])
757  {
758  libmesh_assert_equal_to (*(Point *)_nodes[new_id],
759  *(Point *)_nodes[old_id]);
760  _nodes.erase(new_id);
761  }
762 #else
763  // If we aren't shipping nodes for NodeConstraints, there should be
764  // no reason for renumbering one node onto another.
765  libmesh_assert (!_nodes[new_id]);
766 #endif
767  _nodes[new_id] = nd;
768  _nodes.erase(old_id);
769 }

1201 {
1202  parallel_object_only();
1203 
1204 #ifdef DEBUG
1205  // Make sure our ids and flags are consistent
1206  this->libmesh_assert_valid_parallel_ids();
1207  this->libmesh_assert_valid_parallel_flags();
1208  this->libmesh_assert_valid_parallel_p_levels();
1209 #endif
1210 
1211  LOG_SCOPE("renumber_nodes_and_elements()", "DistributedMesh");
1212 
1213  std::set<dof_id_type> used_nodes;
1214 
1215  // flag the nodes we need
1216  {
1217  element_iterator it = elements_begin();
1218  element_iterator end = elements_end();
1219 
1220  for (; it != end; ++it)
1221  {
1222  Elem * el = *it;
1223 
1224  for (unsigned int n=0; n != el->n_nodes(); ++n)
1225  used_nodes.insert(el->node_id(n));
1226  }
1227  }
1228 
1229  // Nodes not connected to any local elements, and NULL node entries
1230  // in our container, are deleted
1231  {
1232  node_iterator_imp it = _nodes.begin();
1233  node_iterator_imp end = _nodes.end();
1234 
1235  for (; it != end;)
1236  {
1237  Node * nd = *it;
1238  if (!nd)
1239  _nodes.erase(it++);
1240  else if (!used_nodes.count(nd->id()))
1241  {
1242  // remove any boundary information associated with
1243  // this node
1244  this->get_boundary_info().remove (nd);
1245 
1246  // delete the node
1247  delete nd;
1248 
1249  _nodes.erase(it++);
1250  }
1251  else
1252  ++it;
1253  }
1254  }
1255 
1256  if (_skip_renumber_nodes_and_elements)
1257  {
1258  this->update_parallel_id_counts();
1259  return;
1260  }
1261 
1262  // Finally renumber all the elements
1263  _n_elem = this->renumber_dof_objects (this->_elements);
1264 
1265  // and all the remaining nodes
1266  _n_nodes = this->renumber_dof_objects (this->_nodes);
1267 
1268  // And figure out what IDs we should use when adding new nodes and
1269  // new elements
1270  this->update_parallel_id_counts();
1271 
1272  // Make sure our caches are up to date and our
1273  // DofObjects are well packed
1274 #ifdef DEBUG
1275  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->n_nodes(), this->parallel_n_nodes());
1276  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->n_elem(), this->parallel_n_elem());
1277  const dof_id_type pmax_node_id = this->parallel_max_node_id();
1278  const dof_id_type pmax_elem_id = this->parallel_max_elem_id();
1279  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->max_node_id(), pmax_node_id);
1280  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->max_elem_id(), pmax_elem_id);
1281  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->n_nodes(), this->max_node_id());
1282  libmesh_assert_equal_to (this->n_elem(), this->max_elem_id());
1283 
1284  // Make sure our ids and flags are consistent
1285  this->libmesh_assert_valid_parallel_ids();
1286  this->libmesh_assert_valid_parallel_flags();
1287 
1288  // And make sure we've made our numbering monotonic
1289  MeshTools::libmesh_assert_valid_elem_ids(*this);
1290 #endif
1291 }

virtual void libMesh::DistributedMesh::reserve_elem ( const dof_id_type  ne)
inlinevirtual

Reserves space for a known number of elements. Note that this method may or may not do anything, depending on the actual Mesh implementation. If you know the number of elements you will add and call this method before repeatedly calling add_point() the implementation will be more efficient.

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

void libMesh::MeshBase::set_mesh_dimension ( unsigned char  d)
inlineinherited

Resets the logical dimension of the mesh. If the mesh has elements of multiple dimensions, this should be set to the largest dimension. E.g. if the mesh has 1D and 2D elements, this should be set to 2. If the mesh has 2D and 3D elements, this should be set to 3.

void libMesh::MeshBase::skip_partitioning ( bool  skip)
inlineinherited

If true is passed in then this mesh will no longer be (re)partitioned. It would probably be a bad idea to call this on a Serial Mesh before the first partitioning has happened... because no elements would get assigned to your processor pool.

Note that turning on skip_partitioning() can have adverse effects on your performance when using AMR... ie you could get large load imbalances.

However you might still want to use this if the communication and computation of the rebalance and repartition is too high for your application.

Definition at line 709 of file mesh_base.h.

References libMesh::MeshBase::_skip_partitioning.

Referenced by libMesh::UnstructuredMesh::copy_nodes_and_elements().

709 { _skip_partitioning = skip; }

bool _skip_partitioning
Definition: mesh_base.h:1271

libMesh::MeshBase::_skip_partitioning
bool _skip_partitioning
Definition: mesh_base.h:1271
unsigned int libMesh::MeshBase::spatial_dimension ( ) const
inherited

Returns the "spatial dimension" of the mesh. The spatial dimension is defined as:

1 - for an exactly x-aligned mesh of 1D elements 2 - for an exactly x-y planar mesh of 2D elements 3 - otherwise

No tolerance checks are performed to determine whether the Mesh is x-aligned or x-y planar, only strict equality with zero in the higher dimensions is checked. Also, x-z and y-z planar meshes are considered to have spatial dimension == 3.

The spatial dimension is updated during prepare_for_use() based on the dimensions of the various elements present in the Mesh, but is never automatically decreased by this function.

For example, if the user calls set_spatial_dimension(2) and then later inserts 3D elements into the mesh, Mesh::spatial_dimension() will return 3 after the next call to prepare_for_use(). On the other hand, if the user calls set_spatial_dimension(3) and then inserts only x-aligned 1D elements into the Mesh, mesh.spatial_dimension() will remain 3.

Definition at line 155 of file mesh_base.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::_spatial_dimension.

Referenced by libMesh::MeshBase::get_info(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::initialize().

156 {
157  return cast_int<unsigned int>(_spatial_dimension);
158 }

void libMesh::MeshBase::subdomain_ids ( std::set< subdomain_id_type > &  ids) const
inherited

Constructs a list of all subdomain identifiers in the global mesh. Subdomains correspond to separate subsets of the mesh which could correspond e.g. to different materials in a solid mechanics application, or regions where different physical processes are important. The subdomain mapping is independent from the parallel decomposition.

void libMesh::DistributedMesh::update_parallel_id_counts ( )
virtual

Updates parallel caches so that methods like n_elem() accurately reflect changes on other processors

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

Definition at line 148 of file distributed_mesh.C.

References _max_elem_id, _max_node_id, _n_elem, _n_nodes, _next_free_local_elem_id, _next_free_local_node_id, _next_free_unpartitioned_elem_id, _next_free_unpartitioned_node_id, libMesh::MeshBase::_next_unique_id, _next_unpartitioned_unique_id, libMesh::ParallelObject::n_processors(), parallel_max_elem_id(), parallel_max_node_id(), parallel_max_unique_id(), parallel_n_elem(), parallel_n_nodes(), and libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id().

154  _n_nodes = this->parallel_n_nodes();

161  (this->n_processors() + 1) + this->n_processors();

173  ((_max_node_id + this->n_processors() - 1) / (this->n_processors() + 1) + 1) *
174  (this->n_processors() + 1) + this->processor_id();
175 
176 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_UNIQUE_ID
177  _next_unique_id = this->parallel_max_unique_id();
178  _next_unpartitioned_unique_id =
179  ((_next_unique_id-1) / (this->n_processors() + 1) + 1) *
180  (this->n_processors() + 1) + this->n_processors();
181  _next_unique_id =
182  ((_next_unique_id + this->n_processors() - 1) / (this->n_processors() + 1) + 1) *
183  (this->n_processors() + 1) + this->processor_id();
184 #endif
185 }

void libMesh::UnstructuredMesh::write ( const std::string &  name,
MeshData *  mesh_data = libmesh_nullptr 
)
virtualinherited

Write the file specified by name. Attempts to figure out the proper method by the file extension.

In order to write the UNV and TetGen file types, you must also pass a separate pointer to the MeshData object you have been using with this mesh, since these write methods expect it.

Implements libMesh::MeshBase.

Definition at line 617 of file unstructured_mesh.C.

References libMesh::NameBasedIO::write(), and libMesh::UNVIO::write().

619 {
620  LOG_SCOPE("write()", "Mesh");
621 
622  if (mesh_data)
623  {
624  libmesh_deprecated();
625  if (name.rfind(".unv") < name.size())
626  UNVIO(*this, mesh_data).write (name);
627  else
628  libmesh_error_msg("Only UNV output supports MeshData");
629  }
630 
631  NameBasedIO(*this).write(name);
632 }

bool libMesh::MeshBase::_allow_remote_element_removal
protectedinherited

If this is false then even on DistributedMesh remote elements will not be deleted during mesh preparation.

This is true by default.

std::set<unsigned char> libMesh::MeshBase::_elem_dims
protectedinherited

We cache the dimension of the elements present in the mesh. So, if we have a mesh with 1D and 2D elements, this structure will contain 1 and 2.

unsigned int libMesh::MeshBase::_n_parts
protectedinherited

The number of partitions the mesh has. This is set by the partitioners, and may not be changed directly by the user. NOTE The number of partitions need not equal this->n_processors(), consider for example the case where you simply want to partition a mesh on one processor and view the result in GMV.

Definition at line 1237 of file mesh_base.h.

Referenced by libMesh::MeshBase::clear(), libMesh::UnstructuredMesh::copy_nodes_and_elements(), libMesh::MeshBase::n_partitions(), libMesh::MeshBase::recalculate_n_partitions(), and libMesh::MeshBase::set_n_partitions().

UniquePtr<Partitioner> libMesh::MeshBase::_partitioner
protectedinherited

A partitioner to use at each prepare_for_use().

This will be built in the constructor of each derived class, but can be replaced by the user through the partitioner() accessor.

Definition at line 1259 of file mesh_base.h.

Referenced by libMesh::MeshBase::MeshBase(), libMesh::MeshBase::partitioner(), and libMesh::ReplicatedMesh::ReplicatedMesh().

UniquePtr<PointLocatorBase> libMesh::MeshBase::_point_locator
mutableprotectedinherited

A PointLocator class for this mesh. This will not actually be built unless needed. Further, since we want our point_locator() method to be const (yet do the dynamic allocating) this needs to be mutable. Since the PointLocatorBase::build() member is used, and it operates on a constant reference to the mesh, this is OK.

Definition at line 1251 of file mesh_base.h.

Referenced by libMesh::MeshBase::clear_point_locator(), libMesh::MeshBase::point_locator(), and libMesh::MeshBase::sub_point_locator().

UniquePtr<BoundaryInfo> libMesh::MeshBase::boundary_info
inherited

This class holds the boundary information. It can store nodes, edges, and faces with a corresponding id that facilitates setting boundary conditions.

Direct access to this class will be removed in future libMesh versions. Use the get_boundary_info() accessor instead.

Definition at line 1217 of file mesh_base.h.

Referenced by libMesh::MeshBase::get_boundary_info(), and libMesh::BoundaryInfo::sync().
